section1.p: is a tool that can use a to disambiguate a text or a portion of a text that has been analyzed in a project. You tell the project and the to use. Then you can choose a text or a portion of that text and ask to try and disambiguate it.
looks like what is shown in .
There are five buttons you can click. Each is discussed in section below.
You control by using the various buttons. This section briefly describes them. See sections – for more on what happens for the segment and text buttons, respectively.

section2.p: To choose which file to use, click on the Browse button. By convention, files have an extension of “.grm” so this is what the file browser uses.

When you click the “Choose FLEx Project” button, you will see the standard choose project dialog box. You use it to select the project to use. Once the project has been loaded (which may take a while, depending on the size of the project), the names of the project's texts (in the default analysis language) will appear in the bottom left pane. By default, the first text will be selected and all of its segments
By “segment” we mean the portion of the text that FLEx treats as a unit. These are often sentences or clauses. will be shown in the bottom right pane (using the default vernacular language). By default, the first segment will also be selected.

Note that if a given segment does not yet have an analysis for every word in it, the segment will be grayed out. This is because there is no need to try and pass this segment to the . Since at least one word does not have an analysis, cannot parse it: there is no parsing information for that word so the segment is guaranteed to fail to parse.
Please note that you cannot run both and on the same project at the same time.
The smaller button with a question mark in it is used to get this user documentation file or to show the “About” dialog box.
Above the pane containing the texts is a button labeled “Disambiguate & show this text.” You use this button to try and use the to disambiguate this entire text. See section for more.

Above the pane containing the segments of the selected text is a button labeled “Parse & show this segment.” You use this button to try and use the to parse this particular segment. See section for more.

section1.p: When you use the “Parse & show this segment” button for a segment, will pass the parsing information that you entered in to , along with the , and process that segment. The result will be shown in a slightly newer version of the tool (https://​software.​sil.​org/​carla/​pc-patr-browser/). See appendix for more information on this tool.

You use this tool to see all the parses the program produced for this segment using the file. When there are two or more parses, you can show the correct one and then use Parse / Use This Parse menu item (or click on the tool bar button) to have this analysis be recorded in the database for this segment. That is, this segment will be disambiguated, using the information from this parse.
When you are done looking at the results, close the tool and you will return to .

When you use the “Disambiguate & show this text” button, will pass the parsing information for all segments in the text to , along with the , and process all those segments. Since all the segments are processed, this will probably take a while. So please be patient. The result will be shown in the slightly newer version of the tool. See appendix for more information on this tool.
Unlike with parsing a segment (see section ), the result will have as many “sentences” as there are segments in the text.

By default, will disambiguate a segment in the database whenever the result of the parsing uniquely identifies the analysis of each word in the segment. For those cases where there are still ambiguities, you can use the tool to select a given parse to use. Like with parsing a segment, you show the correct parse and then use Parse / Use This Parse menu item (or click on the tool bar button) to have this analysis be recorded in the database for this segment. That is, this segment will be disambiguated, using the information from this parse.
When you are done looking at the results, close the tool and you will return to .
Whenever you exit and restart , it will do the following:

ol.li: remember which file you last chose;
remember which project you last used and open it;
remember which text in that project you last selected; and
remember which segment in that text you last selected.

section1.p: As a result, if the last project you used is large, it may well take a while before finishes starting.
In certain situations, will issue an error message.
Example lists the errors reports along with a brief description of what the error might mean.

td.object: Loading failed. The FieldWorks project is currently open in another application. Close the application and try to run this command aqain.

tr.td: Most likely, is open with the same project. Please close .

section1.p: If you get an error message not in the list above, please report it. See section .
The following items are known to be less than desirable with this version of :

ul.li:
When a word in does not have the “Word Cat" field filled out for a word in the interlinear, will try and guess what the category of the word should be. It does this as follows:
If there is only one morpheme, use its category.
If there are two or more morphemes and only one stem/root, find the stem and use its category. (This could be incorrect if one of the affixes is derivational and changes the category.)
If there are two or more stems, use the category of the left-most one. (This could be incorrect if some other stem is the correct category to use or if the stem compounding results in a different category or if one of the affixes is derivational and changes the category.)
assumes that the comment character in the file is a vertical bar |. If you use something else, the parser will fail every segment.

section1.p: If you have any questions with or find bugs in it, please send an email to andy_black@sil.org.

appendix.p: This appendix briefly covers the various parts of the tool.
Example is a screen shot of what it looks like for one segment using one .

ol.li: the segment in an interlinear form (at the top);
the syntactic tree, if any (left, middle);
the feature structure of the selected node in the tree (right, middle); and

appendix.p: When a node in the tree is selected, the bottom pane will show the rule in the file that produced that node. For example, when clicking on the IP node, it looked like example .

When there is more than one segment, you can use the Sentence menu item options or the first set of arrow buttons on the tool bar to navigate from one sentence to another. (Please note that with , “sentence” is the same as “segment.”)
When there is more than one parse for a given segment, you can use the Parse menu item options or the second set of arrow buttons on the tool bar to navigate from one parse to another.

appendix.secTitle: Another way to edit a file
appendix.p: One challenge with editing a file is that it is a plain text file. If one wants to try and debug a grammar, one has to comment off a large amount of lines. It can get to be tricky.
Some tentative work has been done on a tool that will take a file and convert it to a form that can be used in a tool like the . Some advantages of this are that one can:
A major disadvantage is that once converted to this form, large files are quite slow to load into the .
If you are interested in trying this, please contact andy_black@sil.org.

types.comment: The following types are provided as pre-set examples. You may well want to create your own types that refer to one or more of these. You do that by typing in the names of the types in the types attribute of your type.
